stories.text:
Hi, im Momo digital nomads and art code enthusiastic.

I build web3hunter.co to provide people like me a space where they can find new web3 opportunities, information about salaries and trending projects.

I just get overwhelmed but all the news and the FOMO that i missing something.

It's my first project and first entrepreneur experience, it's really exciting but also 'scary', waiting for what customer's and user gonna say about the platform.

This project is build in public, i want to grow and continue developing the application based on customer feedbacks and user needs.

I will be happy to see what you guys think about it
stories.title: How to find a Web3 job and what salary to ask for?
Microsoft backtracks default browser settings now easier to change in Windows 11
I no longer grade my students’ work – and I wish I had stopped sooner
'Biggest fraud in a generation': The looting of the Covid relief plan

stories.text:
Whenever I'm searching for anything even mildly off the beaten path, it's not uncommon for the top results to be SEO stuffed spam websites, or maybe even real websites that I can't access (like paywalls or requiring adblocker exceptions to proceed). Usually pages from the same domains are top-ranked for other related searches too.

As a user I'd love to be able to tell my search engine to "Never show me results from this domains" (similar to blocking an account on Twitter) – but as far as I can tell there is no way to do this in either Google or DuckDuckGo search.

This seems like such low-hanging fruit to me that I'm wondering if other people have ever wanted this, and if there's actually a reason not to do it.
stories.title: Ask HN: Why do search engines not let you blacklist spam domains?
Impulse Space is betting on a future where launch is cheap
